He studied industrial design at Georgia Tech, taught himself how to build websites, and worked at Cox Interactive Media.

personsLists.name: Forbes 400
bios: Alexandra Daitch owns an estimated 3% stake in Cargill, the largest food company in the world.
She's one of four billionaire sisters who inherited stakes in the company from their father W. Duncan MacMillan, who died in 2006.
Her great-great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, founded the business as a single grain warehouse on the end of an Iowa railroad line in 1865.
The family still owns roughly 90% of Cargill, which did $115 billion in 2018 sales across food, agriculture, financial and industrial divisions.

personsLists.name: Forbes 400
personsLists.title: Co-Founder
bios: Glenn Dubin is the founder of Engineer's Gate, a quantitative trading hedge fund, comprised of 76 employees including 25 PhDs.
Dubin's fortune comes from Highbridge Capital, which he cofounded in 1992 and then sold to JP Morgan Chase in 2004.
He is chairman of Castleton Commodities, an energy firm he bought with an investor group that included Paul Tudor Jones in 2012.
abouts: Dubin is a founding board member of the Robin Hood Foundation, a New York poverty-fighting group.
Dubin and his wife, Eva, an MD and breast cancer survivor, donated millions to found the Dubin Breast Center at Mount Sinai Medical Center, which opened in 2011.

personsLists.name: Forbes 400
personsLists.title: Dr.
bios:
John Farber is the longtime chairman of ICC Industries, which trades basic and specialty chemicals. It also holds a controlling stake in Frutarom.
In May 2018, Frutarom was sold to International Flavors & Fragrances for $7.1 billion.
He started ICC Industries in 1952 as a chemical trading division of his father-in-law's textiles export-import firm, Leslie Kleyman Corporation.
Farber and his family left Romania after his father's business was nationalized following World War II. He reacquired the company in the 1990s.
Farber received his doctorate in polymer chemistry at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn.

personsLists.name: Forbes 400
bios: Frank Fertitta III and his brother, Lorenzo, made the bulk of their fortune through mixed martial arts promoter UFC.
The brothers bought UFC for $2 million in 2001; it sold to an investment group led by WME/IMG for $4 billion in 2016.
They sold their remaining stakes in UFC in August 2017 at a $5 billion valuation.
The Fertittas took their casino business, Red Rock Resorts, public in 2016. It was founded by their father.
They each pledged $7.5 million in 2016 to NYU's Stern School of Business for a scholarship for veterans.
abouts: His daughter Kelley, a vice president at her father's gaming company, got married at a lavish wedding at Red Rock Resorts in September 2018 where Bruno Mars sang.
Frank and Lorenzo got hooked on martial arts after taking weekly lessons in their casino's basement. Soon after, they bought UFC.

personsLists.name: Forbes 400
bios: Lorenzo Fertitta and his brother, Frank, made the bulk of their fortune through mixed martial arts promoter UFC.
They bought UFC for $2 million in 2001; an investment group led by WME/IMG bought it for $4 billion in 2016.
They sold their remaining stakes in UFC in August 2017 at a $5 billion valuation.
The Fertittas took public their casino business, Red Rock Resorts, in 2016. It was founded by their father.
They each pledged $7.5 million in 2016 to NYU's Stern School of Business for a scholarship for veterans.
abouts: The Fertitta brothers got hooked on martial arts after taking weekly lessons in their casino's basement. Soon after, they bought UFC.
Fertitta's son Nicco plays safety for the University of Notre Dame football team.

personsLists.name: Forbes 400
personsLists.title: President and Chairman
bios: Gordon Getty led the sale of his family's Getty Oil to Texaco for $10.1 billion in 1984, after his oil tycoon father J. Paul Getty died in 1976.
Once the sole trustee of the family trust, Getty orchestrated the breakup into six separate trusts in 1985.
In 2015, Gordon's son Andrew Getty died in his Beverly Hills mansion at age 47, reportedly due to medical issues and an unhealthy lifestyle.
Gordon Getty is a classical music composer, whose compositions include the Canterville Ghost, Plump Jack, and Usher House.
Since 2008, Getty has given more than $100 million to his philanthropic foundation, which supports performing arts, music and museum projects.
abouts: An opera and wine aficionado, Getty is a partner in Odette Estate winery in Napa Valley.
The Getty family faced numerous tragedies: The wife of Gordon's brother J. Paul Jr. died of a heroin overdose; J. Paul Jr.'s son was kidnapped by Italian gangsters.
Getty has publicly acknowledged the fact that he has two families: four sons with his wife Ann, and three daughters with Cynthia Beck.

personsLists.name: Forbes 400
bios: Kurzius founded what later became Mailchimp with Ben Chestnut in 2001 as a side project to their web design company.
Mailchimp's email marketing software for small businesses garnered enough customers that in 2007 they committed to it full time.
Wary of giving up control to outside investors, Kurzius and Chestnut bootstrapped growth from profits and took no outside money.
Chestnut and Kurzius each own 50% of Mailchimp, which has expected 2018 revenues of $600 million and is profitable.
He is Chief Customer Officer of the Atlanta-based company, which has nearly 1,000 employees and millions of customers.
abouts: Kurzius was a part-time DJ and competitive skateboarder before getting into web design.
The two cofounders met when Chestnut hired Kurzius to work at Cox Interactive Media's dot-com-era MP3 music service.

personsLists.name: Forbes 400
bios: In 2012, Larsen cofounded Ripple with Mt. Gox founder Jed McCaleb to facilitate international payments for banks using blockchain technology.
Prior to that he cofounded online mortgage lender e-Loan in 1997 and in 2005 cofounded Prosper, a peer-to-peer lender.
Ripple counts Mitsubishi Financial, Bank of America and Santander among its 100-plus customers.
Larsen stepped down as Ripple CEO in December 2016; he stayed on as executive chairman.
abouts: Ripple owns 61% of the total supply of its cryptocurrency, XRP.

personsLists.name: Forbes 400
bios: Jeffrey Lurie is a former college professor but he's more widely known as the outspoken owner of the Philadelphia Eagles NFL team.
In 1983, Lurie took an executive role at General Cinema Corporation, the film company founded by his grandfather.
He started Chestnut Hill Productions in 1985, where he produced a string of mostly forgettable movies.
In 1994, Lurie took out a loan to buy the Philadelphia Eagles for $185 million. The team is now worth $2.5 billion.
Despite having to give up a stake in the Eagles during his 2012 divorce, his 80% of  the team still represents the bulk of his fortune.
abouts: Jeffrey Lurie is a former college professor, but he's more widely known as the outspoken owner of the Philadelphia Eagles NFL team.
Lurie taught social policy at Boston University, after he earned a master's degree there and a doctoral degree at Brandeis.

personsLists.name: Forbes 400
bios: Sarah MacMillan owns an estimated 3% stake in Cargill, the largest food company in the world.
She is one of four billionaire sisters who inherited stakes in the company from their father W. Duncan MacMillan, who died in 2006.
Her great-great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, founded the business as a single grain warehouse on the end of an Iowa railroad line in 1865.
The family still owns roughly 90% of Cargill, which did $115 billion in 2018 sales across food, agriculture, financial and industrial divisions.

personsLists.name: Forbes 400
bios: Phillip Ragon, known as Terry, founded InterSystems, a software company that enables hospitals and banks to analyze big data, in 1978.
Ragon retains full ownership of the company, which had $644 million in 2017 sales.
After a trip to South Africa in 2009 where Terry and Susan saw the ravages of AIDS, they established the Ragon Institute to pursue an HIV vaccine.
Ragon and his wife, Susan Ragon, joined the Giving Pledge in May 2017.
abouts: Ragon spent his high school senior year in Bogota, Colombia and has donated over half a million since 2013 to a religious school there.
Ragon is the son of a U.S. Air Force fighter pilot.

personsLists.name: Forbes 400
bios: Antony "Tony" Ressler cofounded private equity giant Apollo Management with brother-in-law and fellow billionaire Leon Black in 1990.
Like Black, he had previously worked at Wall Street firm Drexel Burnham Lambert, where he was known for his role in the bond department.
In 1997, he cofounded Ares Management, a private equity and investment firm. He stepped down as CEO in December 2017 and became executive chairman.
Ressler owns a minority stake in the Milwaukee Brewers baseball team and is the majority owner of the NBA's Atlanta Hawks.
Ressler has donated millions to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, and sits on the boards of both.
abouts: His sister is married to Apollo co-founder Leon Black.
Ressler is married to TV actress Jami Gertz.

personsLists.name: Forbes 400
bios: Lucy Stitzer chairs Waycrosse, the investment company of the Cargill and MacMillan families, one of the 10 richest clans in America.
Stitzer owns an estimated 3% stake in Cargill, the largest food company in the world.
She's one of four billionaire sisters who inherited stakes in the company from their father W. Duncan MacMillan, who died in 2006.
Her great-great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, founded the business as a single grain warehouse on the end of an Iowa railroad line in 1865.
The family still owns roughly 90% of Cargill, which did $115 billion in 2018 sales across food, agriculture, financial and industrial divisions.

personsLists.name: Forbes 400
bios: Katherine Tanner owns an estimated 3% stake in Cargill, the largest food company in the world.
She's one of four billionaire sisters who inherited stakes in the company from their father W. Duncan MacMillan, who died in 2006.
Her great-great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, founded the business as a single grain warehouse on the end of an Iowa railroad line in 1865.
The family still owns roughly 90% of Cargill, which did $115 billion in 2018 sales across food, agriculture, financial and industrial divisions.

personsLists.name: Forbes 400
bios: Ronald Wanek is the founder of America's largest home furniture manufacturer and retailer, Ashley Furniture.
He started his first furniture manufacturing business, Arcadia Furniture, in 1970 with a loan from his father and money he got from selling his home.
In 1976, he bought retailer Ashley Furniture, which had been around since the 1940s.
He remains chairman of Ashley Furniture; his son, Todd, has been CEO since 2002.
Wanek has donated millions to the Mayo Clinic to help improve treatment for a heart defect that affected his granddaughter at birth.
abouts: Wanek grew up on a dairy farm in Minnesota, where his grandfather and great uncle built furniture as a hobby.
Wanek's family office, Third Lake Capital, owns a wing restaurant chain, hotels and shopping malls.
